question: Do violent video games cause violent crime?

content.source_1: Cunningham, S., Engelstätter, B., & Ward, M. R. (2016). Violent Video Games and Violent Crime — Southern Economic Journal. Using weekly U.S. sales data and crime reports, the authors found that new violent game releases were followed by short-run decreases in assaults and homicides, consistent with an “incapacitation” effect as potential offenders stay home to play.
content.source_2: Anderson, C. A., et al. (2010). Violent Video Game Effects on Aggression, Empathy, and Prosocial Behavior in Eastern and Western Countries: A Meta-Analytic Review — Psychological Bulletin. This meta-analysis concluded that violent games increase aggressive behavior, thoughts, and affect and reduce empathy/prosocial behavior across cultures; proponents argue these effects are a plausible pathway that could elevate risk for real-world violence.
content.source_3: Ferguson, C. J., & Kilburn, J. (2010). Much Ado About Nothing? The Role of Violent Video Game Exposure in Adolescent Aggression and Behavior — Journal of Pediatrics. Reanalyzing the literature while adjusting for publication bias, the authors reported near-zero links between violent games and serious aggression or delinquency, and no evidence tying violent games to violent crime.
content.source_4: Markey, P. M., Markey, C. N., & French, J. E. (2015). Violent Video Games and Real-World Violence: Rhetoric Versus Data — Psychology of Popular Media Culture. Time-series analyses showed that as violent video game sales and interest grew over years, youth and overall violent crime rates declined or remained flat, contradicting a positive population-level link.
content.source_5: Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Association, 564 U.S. 786 (2011). The U.S. Supreme Court reviewed the social science record and concluded the studies did not demonstrate that violent video games cause minors to act aggressively, much less commit violent crimes; it struck down California’s sales restrictions on First Amendment grounds.
content.source_6: U.S. Secret Service & U.S. Department of Education (2002). The Final Report and Findings of the Safe School Initiative. Case studies of school attackers found no consistent profile and did not identify violent media exposure (including video games) as a causal or reliable predictor of violent incidents, emphasizing multifactorial risk over single-cause explanations.
